channel.title: Student Life News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: John Grade to Build Biodegradable Sculptures in Atlanta
item.description: Environmental artist John Grade comes to Atlanta as an Emory University artist-in-residence Nov. 6-19 to design and build large-scale sculptural installations using biodegradable materials.

item.title: Woodward and Bernstein on Campus for Watergate at 40
item.description: In commemoration of the 40th anniversary of the Watergate break-in, legendary news reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein are speaking at Emory for the annual Goodrich C. White Lecture. "Watergate's Impact on Current Day Politics" will be Wednesday, Oct. 26 at 7:30 p.m. in Glenn Memorial Auditorium.

item.title: New Health Course Shifts to Peer-Led, Personalized Approach
item.description: "Health 100: It's Your Health" promotes a personalized approach to healthy living for freshmen, who are mentored by peer health partners. The new course is just one component of Emory's strategic shift in health education, rooted in the predictive health research being conducted on campus.

item.title: CNN Dialogues Forum on Social Media to Feature Top Trendmakers Oct. 12
item.description: CNN Dialogues will host its second event, "Living in the Age of Social Media - the Good, the Bad and the Surprising," on Wednesday, Oct. 12 at 7 p.m. Panelists include musician Pete Wentz, innovator Baratunde Thurston, author Maggie Jackson and pastor Shaun King.

item.title: Emory Cares 4 U Expands Suicide Prevention Outreach
item.description: A university-wide suicide prevention effort empowers its members to recognize and respond to those in need.

item.title: Office of LGBT Life Takes Pride in 20 Years of Growth and Service
item.description: Emory was a pioneer in the campus gay movement. It was among only nine universities nationwide, and the only one in the Southeast, to set up an office serving gay, lesbian and bisexual students.

item.title: Soiree Spotlights Arts Season, Community Artists
item.description: A swirl of music, dance, poetry reading and visual arts exhibits offered a kaleidoscopic look at this year's arts scene at Emory.

item.title: Civil Rights History Interpreted Through Lenses of Student Travelers
item.description: This summer, nine Oxford College students took a tour of places of importance to the American civil rights movement. Starting in Americus, Ga., the students traveled through Alabama and Mississippi, concluding their tour in Memphis.

item.title: Author James Carroll to Speak on 'Jesus Against Himself'
item.description: Award-winning author and Boston Globe columnist James Carroll will give four free public lectures at Emory University this fall on the theme "Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again."

item.title: Athletic Teams Look to Build on Top Rating
item.description: Kicking off the new campaign to retain Emory's standing in overall athletic excellence will be five fall squads, four of whom qualified for NCAA Tournament action a year ago.

item.title: Emory Village Completes Its New Look
item.description: The planting of 50 trees and shaping of a pocket park this fall will complete the 10-year-in-the-making revitalization of Emory Village.

item.title: Parenting a College Student: What To Expect
item.description: Emory University psychology professor Marshall Duke has helped ease the separation process for parents and their newly minted college students with a tremendously popular Emory orientation seminar on "Parenting a College Student: What To Expect."

item.title: Emory Mobile Expands Offerings for Visitors, Emory Community
item.description: Emory University is unveiling the latest version of Emory Mobile. The new application will allow users to view Emory shuttles on their routes in real time, open Emory's iTunesU presence to view new and top downloaded content, search for friends, make new connections with the alumni directory and more.

item.title: Emory Freshmen Take a Hike Into College
item.description: While many of their future classmates are finding their way around campus, some Emory University freshmen will throw on backpacks and hike into college life through Outdoor Emory Adventure Orientation.

item.title: Emory Remains Among Top Ten 'Teach for America' Contributors
item.description: Emory University students are well represented among the 2011 Teach for America corps. Emory is 10th nationally among medium sized universities contributing the greatest number of recent graduates.
